{{stack begin}} {{Taxobox | image = Mycena spec. - Lindsey 6a.jpg | image_width = 235px | image_caption = | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Mycenaceae]] | genus = ''[[Mycena]]'' | species = '''''M. flavoalba''''' | binomial = ''Mycena flavoalba'' | binomial_authority = ([[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]]) [[Lucien Quélet|Quél.]] | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = ''Agaricus flavoalbus'' Fr.
''Agaricus luteoalbus'' [[James Bolton|Bolton]]
''Hemimycena flavoalba'' (Fr.) [[Rolf Singer|Singer]]
''Marasmiellus flavoalbus'' (Fr.) Singer
''Mycena luteoalba'' (Bolton) [[Samuel Frederick Gray|Gray]] }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Mycena flavoalba'' | hymeniumType=gills | capShape = conical | whichGills = adnate | stipeCharacter=bare | sporePrintColor=white | ecologicalType=saprotrophic | howEdible=inedible }} {{stack end}} '''''Mycena flavoalba''''', commonly known as the '''ivory bonnet''', is a species of inedible [[mushroom]] in the [[Mycenaceae]] family. The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is initially conical in shape, before becoming convex and then flattening out; it may reach dimensions of up to {{convert|1.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} across. The cap color is ivory-white to yellowish white, sometimes more yellowish at the center. The tubular [[stipe (mycology)|stems]] are up to {{convert|8|cm|in|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|2.5|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} thick, and have long, coarse white hairs at their bases. The mushroom is found in Europe, the Middle East, and North America, where it grows scattered or in dense groups under [[conifer]]s and on [[humus]] in [[oak]] woods. ==Taxonomy, classification, and naming== First described as ''Agaricus flavoalbus'' by Swedish mycologist [[Elias Magnus Fries]] in 1838, it was assigned its current name in 1872 by [[Lucien Quélet]]. American mycologist [[Rolf Singer]] transferred the species to the genera ''[[Hemimycena]]'' and ''[[Marasmiellus]]'' in 1938 and 1951, respectively. Singer later changed his mind about these placements, and his 1986 ''Agaricales in Modern Taxonomy'', he considered the species a ''Mycena''. The [[binomial name|binomials]] resulting from these transfers are considered [[synonym (taxonomy)|synonyms]]; another synonym is ''Mycena luteoalba'' (Bolton) Gray. ''Mycena flavoalba'' is placed in the [[section (biology)|section]] ''Adonideae'' of the genus ''[[Mycena]]'', alongside species such as {{species|M|ycena|adonis}} and {{species|M|ycena|floridula}}. The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''flavoalba'' ("yellow-white") is a compound of the [[Latin]] adjectives ''flavus'' ("yellow) and ''alba'' ("white"). The mushroom's [[common name]] is the "ivory bonnet". ==Description== [[File:Mycena spec. - Lindsey 6b.jpg|thumb|left|The whitish to creamy white gills are waxy in appearance and consistency.]] The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] of ''M. flavoalba'' is {{convert|1|–|2|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter, conical when young, becoming somewhat bell-shaped, broadly conic or at times nearly convex. It may develop a [[wikt:papilla|papilla]] (a nipple-like structure) in its center. The cap margin is initially pressed against the stem, but in maturity either flares out or curves inward slightly. The cap surface is smooth, moist, and partially translucent, so that the outline of the gills underneath the cap may be seen. The mushroom is [[hygrophanous]] (changing color as it loses or gains moisture), being [[cream (color)|cream]]-[[buff (color)|buff]] to yellowish initially, with a paler (almost white) margin, and fading to buff in the center and yellowish-white along the margin when dry. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is yellowish to white, thick under the disc but otherwise thin, moderately fragile, and without any distinctive odor and taste. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are ascending and somewhat hooked or toothed, narrow at first but becoming rather broad (2.5 mm and becoming 3–4 mm). They are nearly equal in width throughout or slightly [[ventricose]] in age, with a spacing that is close to subdistant. About 18–24 gills reach the stem, with two tiers of lamellulae (short gills that do not extend fully from the cap margin to the stem) that may develop veins running between them. The gills are white to creamy-white with edges that are even and whitish, and waxy in appearance and consistency. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is {{convert|3|–|8|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|1|–|2.5|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} thick, equal, tubular, somewhat elastic, [[wikt:cartilaginous|cartilaginous]], and not particularly fragile. The base of the stem is either [[wikt:strigose|strigose]] (covered with sharp, straight, stiff white hairs) or surrounded with a matted white [[mycelium]]. Above the base, the stem is smooth, and [[wikt:pruinose|pruinose]] toward the apex. When moist it is translucent with slight ripples running transversely, and white to pale yellow in color. ''Mycena flavoalba'' is considered inedible. ===Microscopic characteristics=== The [[spore]]s are 7–9 by 3–4.5 [[micrometre|μm]], [[wikt:ellipsoid|ellipsoid]], and [[nonamyloid]]. The [[basidia]] (spore-bearing cells) are four-spored. The pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia ([[cystidium|cystidia]] found on the face and edge of a gill, respectively) are similar in structure and abundant, [[wikt:ventricose|ventricose]] with long, rather narrow necks, and measure 46–62 by 9–14 μm. The neck is often encrusted with a [[wikt:mucilaginous|mucilaginous]] substance, but it is otherwise smooth and [[hyaline]]. The flesh of the gill is [[wikt:homogenous|homogenous]], and [[staining|stains]] pale yellow in iodine. The flesh of the cap has a thin, poorly differentiated [[wikt:pellicle|pellicle]] (a thin membrane), a somewhat differentiated hypoderm (that is most pronounced in old caps) and the remainder is made up of somewhat enlarged cells that stain pale yellow in iodine.Smith, p.166–68. ===Similar species=== ''Mycena flavoalba'' bears resemblance to some members of the genus ''[[Hemimycena]]'', such as ''[[Hemimycena lactea|H. lactea]]'' and ''[[Hemimycena delectabilis|H. delectabilis]]''. It can be distinguished from these species by its white to yellowish cap, and differences in the shape of both its spores and caulocystidia (cystidia on the stem). ''[[Hemimycena conidiogena|H. conidiogena]]'', a Spanish species newly described from in 2005, is also similar in appearance, but differs in the distribution of [[pigment]] in the cap, and the differential staining in response to the dye [[cresyl blue]]—''M. flavoalba'' is positive, while ''H. conidiogena'' is negative. ==Habitat and distribution== The fruit bodies of ''Mycena flavoalba'' grow scattered to densely gregarious on [[pine needle|needle]] beds under [[conifer]]s, and on [[humus]] in [[oak]] woods during the autumns months. Although generally rare, the species sometimes occurs in large quantities in certain localities. In the United States, it has been collected from [[Colorado]], [[Idaho]], [[Michigan]], [[North Carolina]], [[Oregon]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[Wyoming]], [[Florida]], and [[Kansas]]. It is also found in Europe, and Israel. The species is listed as "Least Concern" in the Danish [[Regional Red List|Red Data Book]]. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em|refs= {{cite journal |author=Binyamin N. |year=1973 |title=White-spored agarics new to Israel |journal=Israel Journal of Botany |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=38–46 |issn=0021-213X}} {{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0269-915X(09)80644-7 |author=Emmett EE. |year=1993 |title=British ''Mycena'' species, 5 |journal=Mycologist |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=63–67 |issn=0269-915X}} {{cite journal |author=Gerhardt E. |year=1990 |title=Checkliste der Großpilze von Berlin (West) 1970-1990 |journal=Englera |volume= |issue=13 |pages=3–5, 7–251 |jstor=3776760 }} {{cite journal |vauthors=Moreau PA, Vila J, Pérez-de-Gregorio MA, Llistosella J, Llimona X |year=2005 |title=''Hemimycena conidiogena'', a new cistophilous basidiomycete |journal=Mycotaxon |volume=91 |pages=323–32 |url=http://botanique.univ-lille2.fr/fileadmin/user_upload/documents/pdf_pam/Moreau_Hemimyc_conidio_2005.pdf |accessdate=2010-09-27}} {{cite book |title=Common Florida Mushrooms |author=Kimbrough JW. |year=2000 |publisher=University of Florida, Extension Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences |isbn=978-0-916287-30-6 |pages=164–65}} {{cite journal |author=Quélet L.|year=1872 |title=Les Champignons de Jura et des Vosges |journal=Mémoires de la [[Société d'Émulation de Montbéliard]] |volume=5 |page=103 |language=French}} {{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3626234 |vauthors=Shaffer RL, Rogerson CT |year=1952 |title=Notes on the fleshy fungi of Kansas |journal=Transactions of the Kansas Academy of Science |volume=55 |issue=3 |pages=282–86 |jstor=3626234 }} {{cite journal |author=Singer R. |year=1943 |title=Das System der Agaricales.
